content.description: Start on a massive jug and a huge foothold towards the bottom, and move hand over hand from jug to jug up to the left till you top out.
content.location: Take the main trail from the parking area, and stick right both times when the trail splits, continuing up the hill. Once at the top of the hill, take the left trail. Walk down that trail for a couple minutes until the next trail split, take the left again, and walk down into the land depression to the right. Continue along the depression until you see a massive boulder. This climb is on the down right side **** to the right of "Dreaming of Falling."

content.description: Start on the lowest and larger of the two crimp rails, and use a tiny foot to start. Move to the next crimp rail. Make an easy move up to massive underclings, adjust your feet up, and easily scale over to top out.
content.location: From the parking area, start on the main trail. Once the trail splits into two directions, go right up the hill. Near the top of the short hill to the left, there will be a prominent boulder right next to the trail.

content.description: Start with your left hand up high and your right hand underclinging the bottom right of the rock next to the tree. Work your right hand up two slopers before moving your left hand to a sidepull and getting an easy topout.
content.location: Take the main trail from the parking area, and stick right both times when the trail splits, continuing up the hill. The boulder is at the top of the hill right along the trail.

content.description: Start with your left hand on a crimp low down near your feet and your right hand way up high on a sloper, and bring your left hand up to the next sloper in line. Cross over you right hand, and move your left hand to the further left hold, a small crimp. Move your right foot up, and use reach to grab the topout jug.
content.location: Take the main trail from the parking area, and stick right both times when the trail splits, continuing up the hill. The boulder is at the top of the hill right along the trail.

content.description: Use the lower rock for foot holds and the higher rock for handholds. Place your left hand on an undercling along the edge and your right hand on a crimp on the flat face. Move your hands to the next crimp and then to a massive jug higher up along the edge, adjusting your feet on micro footholds on the lower rock as needed. Move your hand up to a massive hug, and precariously top out on a razor's edge.
content.location: Take the main trail from the parking area, and stick right both times when the trail splits, continuing up the hill. Once at the top of the hill, take the left trail. Walk down that trail for a couple minutes until the next trail split, take the left again, and walk down into the land depression to the right. The boulder will be right at the beginning to the right.

content.description: Start with both of your hands on the large quartz rail, and use some absolutely terrible footholds. Shoot your right hand to the massive jug to the right. Use the easy hold to move your left hand up to a sidepull crimp and your right hand to another sidepull crimp. Adjust your left hand to a better, higher up crimp. Move your feet higher and higher, and top out.
content.location: Take the main trail from the parking area, and stick right both times when the trail splits, continuing up the hill. Once at the top of the hill, take the left trail. Walk down that trail for a couple minutes until you see a depression in the ground (a very rectangular cutout, rock on both sides) to the left right before the next trail split. This line of rock can be found by walking through this depression, coming out the other side, and it will be to the left up a short incline. It is ****next to "Chocolate Cake for One" right to the right.

content.description: Start on the lower section of rock on a crimp and jug, easily get up onto the ledge, then use a number of large crimps and jugs with large foot holds to move up, and then top out.
content.location: Take the main trail from the parking area, and stick right both times when the trail splits, continuing up the hill. Once at the top of the hill, take the left trail. Walk down that trail for a couple minutes until the next trail split, take the left again, and walk down into the land depression to the right. Continue along the depression until you see a massive boulder. This climb is on the down right side **** to the left of "What Even Is This?"

content.description: Your right hand starts on a massive undercling jug and your left hand on a crimp. Make sure to move some leaves out of the way to expose a nice foothold for your left foot, and awkardly place a high foot to the right. Really pull yourself up from that sitdown start, and move left start to a higher crimp, and bump it again to a higher crimp. Adjust your right hand up to a crimp, adjust your feet higher, then move to large jugs at the top, and top out.
content.location: Take the main trail from the parking area, and stick right both times when the trail splits, continuing up the hill. Once at the top of the hill, take the left trail. Walk down that trail for a couple minutes until you see a depression in the ground (a very rectangular cutout, with rock on both sides) to the left right before the next trail split. This line of rock can be found by walking through this depression and it being towards the end on the right.

content.description: Start to the left with a sit down start with a massive undercling. Move one hand up to the next undercling and then both hands up to the crimpy slopers. The foot holds are fairly wet and very small, so be cautious. Traverse right, moving your right hand over to the large quartz. Bump your left hand to where your right hand was just. Move your right hand up to a nice crimp and your left hand to a sharp crimp. Move your right hand to a massive side jug, adjust your feet way up, and top out.
content.location: Take the main trail from the parking area, and stick right both times when the trail splits, continuing up the hill. Once at the top of the hill, take the left trail. Walk down that trail for a couple minutes until you see a depression in the ground (a very rectangular cutout with rock on both sides) to the left right before the next trail split. This line of rock can be found by walking through this depression, coming out the other side, and it will be to the left up a short incline. This is **** right next to "I Scream Sometimes" to the left.

content.description: This is public, wooded conservation land with a large amount of scattered rocks and boulders. A large number of the boulders are currently undeveloped and need a good amount of cleaning of lichen and moss. One part of the area has a "crag" of boulders of probably 10-20 in a line that haven't been touched yet. There are potential boulders ranging from 12 to 30 feet.
